data.title: Glass (1958)
data.meta_description: This short documentary, shot in the glass factories of Leerdam and Schiedam, demonstrates how glass blowers do their work. But thanks to the superbly edited ballet of working hands and the sequence of mechanical motions of the engines, is it especially a cinematic tour de force. That the industry can’t do without man’s involvement is shown in the scene where we hear the voice of Haanstra himself counting the bottles on the conveyor belt, until one bottle breaks…
data.text:
A vignette of mundane industrialization transformed into jazzy experimentation with audiovisual synchrony and cacophonies to break the psychological balance. Haanstra applies full artistic freedom here and the Academy was, of course, impressed, but so were worldwide audiences even up to this day.

Speaking of the latter, any eroticism implication that might be derived from the modern viewer are actually amusing in the sense that the current preconceived notions and personal mentalities are way more involved in it than the true original intentions of Haanstra. I wouldn't really know about the director, though, but I am beholding the amusing reactions of today and that leaves food for thought, but also personal reflection. I see more a gorgeous improvised concert of a mundane and exhausting industrial routine than an exercise of suggestion.

92/100
